title: 109_s2046
content: The Act is titled the "National Methamphetamine Information Clearinghouse Act of 2005" and defines terms such as "Council," "drug endangered children," "National Methamphetamine Information Clearinghouse," and "qualified entity." Establishment of Clearinghouse and Advisory Council. Established under the Attorney General, the National Methamphetamine Information Clearinghouse and Advisory Council consist of 10 members appointed by the Attorney General, including representatives from law enforcement agencies, nongovernmental organizations, and the Department of Health and Human Services. The National Methamphetamine Information Clearinghouse and Advisory Council, established under the Attorney General, consists of 10 members appointed for 3 years. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The National Methamphetamine Information Clearinghouse and Advisory Council, established under the Attorney General, consists of 10 members appointed for 3 years. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. NMIC requirements and review are outlined in Section 4. The NMIC promotes sharing information on methamphetamine programs and grants, including a toll-free number and website with details on effects, treatment programs, and grants. The NMIC website allows qualified entities to submit information on successful programs related to methamphetamine. It includes a restricted section for law enforcement with helpful strategies and training. Public access is available to all non-restricted information. The Council reviews and evaluates information submitted by qualified entities for posting on the NMIC website to combat methamphetamine production, use, or effects. They determine if the item meets posting requirements and consult with the Attorney General to decide if it should be in a restricted section. When a qualified entity submits an item, the Council will either post it on the website or notify the entity of reasons for not posting it and any modifications needed for posting. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorized appropriations for the establishment and operation of the NMIC and Council for fiscal year 2006 and subsequent years.
